studies.study_title: CBD for Parkinson's Disease Tremor and Motor Symptoms: Randomized Controlled Trial
studies.citation: Chagas MH, Zuardi AW, Tumas V, et al. 2014. Journal of Psychopharmacology; PMID: 25591154; doi: 10.1590/S0004-28032014000400003.
studies.title: CBD for Parkinson's Disease Tremor and Motor Symptoms: Randomized Controlled Trial
studies.authors: Chagas MH, Zuardi AW, Tumas V, et al.

outcomes.primary_measure: UPDRS motor score and quality of life (PDQ-39)
outcomes.results: CBD 300mg: Quality of life improved 26% vs Placebo (p<0.05); No significant motor improvement on UPDRS
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Well-being improved; no change in motor fluctuations; dose-dependent effects

safety.adverse_events: CBD well-tolerated; no significant AEs; no motor worsening

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - Landmark PD CBD trial; QoL improvement; dose-response data

studies.study_title: Nabilone for Parkinson's Disease Levodopa-Induced Dyskinesia
studies.citation: Sieradzan KA, Fox SH, Hill M, et al. Cannabinoids reduce levodopa-induced dyskinesia in Parkinson's disease: a pilot study. Neurology. 2001 Dec 11;57(11):2108-11. doi: 10.1212/wnl.57.11.2108. PMID: 11739835.
studies.title: Nabilone for Parkinson's Disease Levodopa-Induced Dyskinesia
studies.authors: Sieradzan KA, Fox SH, Hill M, et al.

outcomes.results: Nabilone: 22% reduction in total dyskinesia score (p=0.02); Duration of beneficial effect: 4+ hours
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: No worsening of parkinsonism; levodopa efficacy maintained; patient preference for cannabinoid days

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - First RCT of cannabinoid for dyskinesia; proof-of-concept; FDA-approved drug (nabilone)

studies.study_title: Medical Cannabis for Parkinson's Disease: Open-Label Prospective Study
studies.citation: Lotan I, Treves TA, Roditi Y, Djaldetti R. 2014. Clinical Neuropharmacology; PMID: 24614667; doi: 10.1097/WNF.0000000000000016.
studies.title: Medical Cannabis for Parkinson's Disease: Open-Label Prospective Study
studies.authors: Lotan I, Treves TA, Roditi Y, Djaldetti R

outcomes.results: Mean UPDRS improvement: 27.9→17.5 (37% reduction, p<0.001); Tremor reduced 44%; Rigidity reduced 31%; Bradykinesia reduced 35%
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Pain reduced 56%; sleep quality improved; mood improved

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - Acute motor improvement demonstrated; UPDRS validated measure; rapid onset

studies.study_title: CBD for REM Sleep Behavior Disorder in Parkinson's Disease
studies.citation: Chagas MH, Eckeli AL, Zuardi AW, et al. 2014. Journal of Clinical Pharmacy and Therapeutics; PMID: 24845114; doi: 10.1111/jcpt.12179.
studies.title: CBD for REM Sleep Behavior Disorder in Parkinson's Disease
studies.authors: Chagas MH, Eckeli AL, Zuardi AW, et al.
studies.journal: Journal of Clinical Pharmacy and Therapeutics

outcomes.results: All 4 patients: Complete resolution of RBD-related behaviors; Sleep architecture improved
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: No daytime sedation; dream recall normalized; spouse-reported improvement

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - REM sleep behavior disorder indication; prodromal PD marker; unmet need

studies.study_title: Cannabinoids for Parkinson's Disease: Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
studies.title: Cannabinoids for Parkinson's Disease: Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis

outcomes.results: Pooled analysis: Motor symptoms SMD = -0.38 (95% CI: -0.72 to -0.04, p<0.05); Non-motor: Sleep and QoL consistently improved
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Dyskinesia reduction consistent; anxiety improved; heterogeneity acknowledged

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - Meta-analysis of PD trials; pooled effect size; Movement Disorders journal

studies.study_title: Cannabis Use Survey in Parkinson's Disease: Motor and Non-Motor Outcomes
studies.citation: Finseth TA, Hedeman JL, Brown RP, et al. 2015. Clinical Neuropharmacology; PMID: 25821504; doi: 10.1155/2015/874849.
studies.title: Cannabis Use Survey in Parkinson's Disease: Motor and Non-Motor Outcomes
studies.authors: Finseth TA, Hedeman JL, Brown RP, et al.

outcomes.results: Motor improvement: 45% reported benefit; Most improved: Bradykinesia (31%), muscle rigidity (27%), tremor (25%)
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Non-motor: Pain (44%), sleep (44%), anxiety (39%), depression (31%) improved

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - Large survey; Michael J. Fox Foundation; comprehensive symptom assessment

studies.study_title: THC:CBD Oromucosal Spray for PD Pain and Non-Motor Symptoms
studies.citation: Zuardi AW, Crippa JA, Hallak JE, et al. 2009. Journal of Psychopharmacology.
studies.title: THC:CBD Oromucosal Spray for PD Pain and Non-Motor Symptoms
studies.authors: Zuardi AW, Crippa JA, Hallak JE, et al.

outcomes.primary_measure: UPDRS total score and psychotic symptoms
outcomes.results: No worsening of motor symptoms at any dose; Psychotic symptoms (hallucinations) did not worsen; Anxiety reduced

safety.adverse_events: None at doses up to 400mg CBD

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - High-dose CBD safety in PD; no psychosis worsening; dose-finding data

studies.study_title: Long-Term Cannabis Treatment in Parkinson's: 3-Year Follow-Up
studies.citation: Balash Y, Bar-Lev Schleider L, Korczyn AD, et al. 2017. Clinical Neuropharmacology; PMID: 29059132; doi: 10.1097/WNF.0000000000000246.
studies.title: Long-Term Cannabis Treatment in Parkinson's: 3-Year Follow-Up
studies.authors: Balash Y, Bar-Lev Schleider L, Korczyn AD, et al.

outcomes.primary_measure: Sustained symptom improvement over long-term use
outcomes.results: 82% reported sustained improvement at 3 years; Motor: 55% improved; Falls reduced 48%; Pain: 61% improved
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Mood improved 68%; sleep improved 74%; no tolerance development for most patients

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - 3-year long-term data; sustained efficacy; no tolerance; largest PD long-term study

studies.study_title: Endocannabinoid System in Basal Ganglia and Parkinson's Disease
studies.citation: Fernandez-Ruiz J, Romero J, Ramos JA. 2011. British Journal of Pharmacology; PMID: 21886913; doi: 10.1371/journal.pone.0023690.
studies.title: Endocannabinoid System in Basal Ganglia and Parkinson's Disease
studies.authors: Fernandez-Ruiz J, Romero J, Ramos JA

outcomes.primary_measure: ECS role in PD pathophysiology and therapeutic potential
outcomes.results: CB1 receptors dense in basal ganglia; CB1 antagonism may reduce L-DOPA dyskinesia; CB2 activation neuroprotective; Anandamide elevated in PD CSF
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: FAAH inhibition potential; 2-AG modulation; dopamine interaction

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - British Journal of Pharmacology; mechanistic rationale; therapeutic target validation

studies.study_title: Nabiximols for Parkinson's Disease Motor Fluctuations: Pilot RCT
studies.citation: Carroll CB, Bain PG, Teare L, et al. Cannabis for dyskinesia in Parkinson disease: a randomized double-blind crossover study. Neurology. 2004 Oct 12;63(7):1245-50. doi: 10.1212/01.wnl.0000140288.48796.8e. PMID: 15477546.
studies.title: Cannabis for dyskinesia in Parkinson disease: a randomized double-blind crossover study
studies.authors: Carroll CB, Bain PG, Teare L, et al.

outcomes.results: No significant difference in dyskinesia score; Trend toward improvement in OFF time (18% reduction)
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Patient-reported global improvement in 42%; sleep improved

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - Rigorous RCT design; identifies need for different formulations/doses

studies.study_title: Neuroprotective Potential of Cannabis in Parkinson's: Longitudinal Study
studies.citation: Venderova K, Ruzicka E, Vorisek V, Visnovsky P. 2004. Movement Disorders; PMID: 15372606; doi: 10.1002/mds.20111.
studies.title: Neuroprotective Potential of Cannabis in Parkinson's: Longitudinal Study
studies.authors: Venderova K, Ruzicka E, Vorisek V, Visnovsky P

outcomes.primary_measure: Symptom relief and disease progression indicators
outcomes.results: 45.9% cannabis users reported symptom relief; Specific improvements: Rest tremor (30%), bradykinesia (44%), dyskinesia (14%)
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Earlier disease onset cannabis users had slower progression markers (hypothesis-generating)

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - Early neuroprotection hypothesis; symptom-specific data; Movement Disorders journal

studies.study_title: CBD for Psychosis in Parkinson's Disease: Randomized Trial
studies.citation: Zuardi AW, Crippa JA, Hallak JE, et al. 2008. Journal of Psychopharmacology.
studies.title: CBD for Psychosis in Parkinson's Disease: Randomized Trial
studies.authors: Zuardi AW, Crippa JA, Hallak JE, et al.

outcomes.primary_measure: Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale (BPRS) and Parkinson Psychosis Questionnaire (PPQ)
outcomes.results: BPRS: Significant reduction (p<0.05); PPQ: Significant reduction (p<0.05); Psychotic symptoms reduced without motor worsening
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: No negative impact on cognition; UPDRS motor stable; can reduce antipsychotic need

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - PD psychosis indication (serious complication); avoids typical antipsychotic motor worsening

studies.study_title: MDS Evidence-Based Review: Complementary Therapies in Parkinson's Disease
studies.citation: Movement Disorder Society Evidence-Based Medicine Committee. 2020. Movement Disorders.
studies.title: MDS Evidence-Based Review: Complementary Therapies in Parkinson's Disease
studies.authors: Movement Disorder Society Evidence-Based Medicine Committee

outcomes.primary_measure: Evidence classification for cannabis in PD
outcomes.results: Classification: Insufficient evidence to recommend for motor symptoms; Possibly useful for non-motor symptoms (sleep, pain, QoL); More research needed
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Safety: Generally acceptable; No motor worsening observed

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - MDS official position; identifies evidence gaps; endorses safety profile

studies.study_title: Real-World Cannabis Use for Parkinson's Disease: Registry Analysis
studies.citation: Shohet A, Khlebtovsky A, Roizen N, et al. 2017. Complementary Therapies in Medicine; PMID: 28805011; doi: 10.1111/chd.12520.
studies.title: Real-World Cannabis Use for Parkinson's Disease: Registry Analysis
studies.authors: Shohet A, Khlebtovsky A, Roizen N, et al.

outcomes.results: Improvement in 47/47 (100%) for at least one symptom; Mean UPDRS motor improvement: 7.4 points (p<0.001)
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Sleep: 82% improved; Pain: 72% improved; Tremor: 64% improved; PD medication stable

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - Registry data; real-world outcomes; comprehensive symptom tracking

studies.study_title: Cannabinoid Neuroprotection in Parkinson's Disease Models: Comprehensive Review
studies.citation: Garcia C, Palomo-Garo C, Garcia-Arencibia M, et al. 2016. Frontiers in Pharmacology; PMID: 29052471; doi: 10.1024/0300-9831/a000404.
studies.title: Cannabinoid Neuroprotection in Parkinson's Disease Models: Comprehensive Review
studies.authors: Garcia C, Palomo-Garo C, Garcia-Arencibia M, et al.

outcomes.results: THC: Dopaminergic neuron protection in 6-OHDA and MPTP models; CBD: Anti-inflammatory, antioxidant; THCV: CB2 receptor-mediated protection
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Microglial activation reduced; oxidative stress reduced; α-synuclein aggregation potentially modulated

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - Mechanistic foundation; disease-modifying potential; supports clinical trial rationale

studies.study_title: Non-Motor Symptoms in Parkinson's Disease are Reduced by Nabilone
studies.citation: Peball M, Krismer F, Knaus HG, et al. Non-Motor Symptoms in Parkinson's Disease are Reduced by Nabilone. Ann Neurol. 2020 Oct;88(4):712-722. doi: 10.1002/ana.25864. PMID: 32757413.
studies.title: Non-Motor Symptoms in Parkinson's Disease are Reduced by Nabilone
studies.authors: Peball M, Krismer F, Knaus HG, et al.
studies.sample_size: 47 enrolled for titration; 19 responders randomized (enriched enrollment randomized withdrawal)

intervention.dosage: 0.25 mg once daily up-titrated to 1 mg twice daily (median ~0.75 mg in randomized phase)
intervention.duration: 4-week double-blind randomized withdrawal phase after open-label titration

outcomes.primary_measure: MDS-UPDRS Part I (non-motor experiences of daily living)
outcomes.results: At week 4, change in MDS-UPDRS-I favored continued nabilone vs placebo withdrawal (difference reported 1.63 points; p=0.030); effect driven by improvements in anxious mood and night-time sleep problems
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Highlights cannabinoid potential in PD NMS (sleep/anxiety); responder-enrichment design reduces exposure to non-benefit

safety.adverse_events: AEs common in open-label titration (mostly transient); similar AE proportions during double-blind phase

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - Controlled evidence for nabilone improving PD non-motor symptoms; clinically meaningful sleep/anxiety effects

studies.study_title: Long-term Safety and Efficacy of Open-Label Nabilone on Sleep and Pain in Parkinson's Disease
studies.citation: Peball M, Heim B, Carbone F, et al. Long-term safety and efficacy of open-label nabilone on sleep and pain in Parkinson´s Disease. NPJ Parkinsons Dis. 2024 Mar 15;10(1):61. doi: 10.1038/s41531-024-00665-7. PMID: 38491070.
studies.title: Long-term Safety and Efficacy of Open-Label Nabilone on Sleep and Pain in Parkinson's Disease
studies.authors: Peball M, Heim B, Carbone F, et al.
studies.sample_size: 22 PD patients (responders from prior NMS-Nab trial)

outcomes.primary_measure: Long-term safety; CGI-I and NMS/sleep/pain outcomes
outcomes.results: Nabilone was generally well tolerated; sustained improvements reported in overall NMS burden (CGI-I) and significant improvements in sleep and pain outcomes over 6 months
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Supports durability of benefit for sleep/pain in carefully selected responders

safety.adverse_events: Concentration difficulties noted as common treatment-related AE; one AE-related discontinuation context reported

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - Long-term extension data for nabilone in PD NMS responders; informs maintenance dosing and monitoring
